senses.de: To remain informed or in control of something; to keep up with the latest developments or information.
senses.ex: I need to stay on top of my emails so I don't miss any important deadlines.
cl: stay on top of the news
stay on top of your work
stay on top of the latest developments
stay on top of current events
struggling to stay on top of everything
managing to stay on top of the workload
it's important to stay on top of your finances

Tips.title: Managing workload
Tips.description: Use 'stay on top of' when discussing managing a heavy workload or multiple tasks.
Tips.example: To stay on top of all my projects, I use a detailed to-do list and schedule regular check-ins.

Tips.title: Staying informed
Tips.description: Use 'stay on top of' to describe keeping up-to-date with news, trends, or information.
Tips.example: It's crucial to stay on top of industry trends if you want to remain competitive.

Tips.title: Maintaining control
Tips.description: Use 'stay on top of' to convey being in control of a situation and preventing problems.
Tips.example: By staying on top of maintenance, we can avoid costly repairs in the future.

keep up with.wordDefinition: 'Stay on top of' emphasizes being in control and proactive, while 'keep up with' focuses on not falling behind.

be aware of.wordDefinition: 'Stay on top of' implies active engagement, while 'be aware of' simply means having knowledge of something.

monitor.wordDefinition: 'Stay on top of' is more general, while 'monitor' suggests close observation and tracking.
